turns.speaker: PIGLET
turns.text: Well,  what seems to be the trouble?

turns.speaker: GALAHAD
turns.text: They're doctors?

turns.speaker: GALAHAD
turns.text: No look, really, this isn't nescess ...

turns.speaker: PIGLET
turns.text: We must examine you.

turns.speaker: GALAHAD
turns.text: There's nothing wrong with ... that.

turns.speaker: PIGLET
turns.text: Please ... we are doctors.

turns.speaker: GALAHAD
turns.text: No, no, this cannot be.   I am sworn to chastity!

turns.speaker: PIGLET
turns.text: Back to your bed!  At once!

turns.speaker: GALAHAD
turns.text: I'm sorry, I must go.

turns.speaker: LAUNCELOT
turns.text: Oh, fair one, behold your humble servant, Sir Launcelot, from the Court of Camelot.  I have come to take you ...  away ... I'm terribly sorry ...

turns.speaker: PRINCE
turns.text: You got my note!

turns.speaker: LAUNCELOT
turns.text: Well ... yes ...

turns.speaker: PRINCE
turns.text: You've come to rescue me?

turns.speaker: LAUNCELOT
turns.text: Well ... yes ... but I hadn't realised ...

turns.speaker: PRINCE
turns.text: I knew that someone would come.  I knew ... somewhere out there ... there must be ...

turns.speaker: LAUNCELOT
turns.text: I'm ... er ... Sir Launcelot, sir.

turns.speaker: PRINCE
turns.text: He's come to rescue me, father.

turns.speaker: LAUNCELOT
turns.text: Well, let's not jump to conclusions ...

turns.speaker: PRINCE
turns.text: Hurry!

turns.speaker: LAUNCELOT
turns.text: I am, sir. I am a Knight of King Arthur.

turns.speaker: TALL KNIGHT
turns.text: When you have found the shrubbery, place the shrubbery here, beside this shrubbery ... only slightly higher, so you get a two-level effect with a path through the middle.

turns.speaker: OTHER KNIGHTS
turns.text: A path!  A little path for the late Knights of Ni!

turns.speaker: TALL KNIGHT
turns.text: When you have found the shrubbery, then you must cut down the mightiest tree in the forest ... with a herring.

turns.speaker: OTHER KNIGHTS
turns.text: Yes!  With a herring!  With a herring!  Cut down with a herring!

turns.speaker: OTHER KNIGHTS
turns.text: Oh!

turns.speaker: TALL KNIGHT
turns.text: Don't say that word.

turns.speaker: TALL KNIGHT
turns.text: Stop saying the word!

turns.speaker: OTHER KNIGHTS
turns.text: Stop saying the word!  The word we cannot hear!  The word ...

turns.speaker: OTHER KNIGHTS
turns.text: They're all saying the word ...

turns.speaker: TALL KNIGHT
turns.text: Stop saying it.  AAAArghh! ... I've said it ...

turns.speaker: OTHER KNIGHTS
turns.text: You've said it!  Aaaaarghhh! ... We've said it ... Wwe're all saying it.

turns.speaker: ROBIN
turns.text: You tit.  I soiled my armour I was so scared!

turns.speaker: TIM
turns.text: That rabbit's got a vicious streak. It's a killer!

turns.speaker: ROBIN
turns.text: |      You turd! +      Mangy scots git!

turns.speaker: TIM
turns.text: Look.  I'm warning you.

turns.speaker: ROBIN
turns.text: What's he do?  Nibble your bum?

turns.speaker: TIM
turns.text: Well, It's got huge ... very sharp ... it can jump a... look at the bones.

turns.speaker: ROBIN
turns.text: I done it again.

turns.speaker: TIM
turns.text: Did I tell you?  Did you listen to me?  Oh no, no, you knew better didn't you?  No, it's just an ordinary rabbit isn't it.  The names you called me.  Well, don't say I didn't tell you.

turns.speaker: ROBIN
turns.text: Er, That's ... That's enough music for a while, lads. It Looks as though like there's dirty work afoot.

turns.speaker: SINGERS
turns.text: Brave, Sir Rob ...

turns.speaker: ROBIN
turns.text: Shut up.

turns.speaker: SINGERS
turns.text: He is brave Sir Robin, brave Sir Robin, who ...

turns.speaker: ROBIN
turns.text: Shut up.  Oh, nobody really. just passing through.

turns.speaker: SINGERS
turns.text: Brave Sir Robin ran away.

turns.speaker: ROBIN
turns.text: I didn't.

turns.speaker: SINGERS
turns.text: Bravely ran away, away.

turns.speaker: ROBIN
turns.text: No, no, no.

turns.speaker: SINGERS
turns.text: When danger reared its ugly head, He bravely turned his tail and fled Yes, Brave Sir Robin turned about And gallantly he chickened out Bravely taking to his feet He beat a very brave retreat Bravest of the brave Sir Robin Petrified of being dead Soiled his pants then brave Sir Robin Turned away and fled.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: So?

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: So, there are rules.  Things you do and things you don't do.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: I was just telling the woman how I feel, for God's sake.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: You don't tell Her Majesty how you feel.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: I speak as I find, Archie.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: Not down south you don't.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: So what did Ponsonby do when she started shouting?

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: I think he nearly ruptured his truss.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: How much?

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: Seventy a year.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Not bad, not bad.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: How about yourself?

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Sixty.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: That's pretty good for a ghillie.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Prince Leopold?  Is he the one who bleeds all day?  So what does his valet do?  Wash his poultices for him?

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: It's better than shovelling horse shit.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: If you were looking for promotion, you should have picked one of the healthier ones.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: She's hardly a full hamper herself.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: It's only grief makes her like she is.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: Three years, John.  Is that not a bit long to be grieving?

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: She loved him.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: Come on, man.  There's love and there's ...

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: You know what I mean.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: I'm not sure I do, Archie.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: There's love and there's behaving like you do because there's nobody to tell you not to.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Which one of us is she flirting with?

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: The good-looking one.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Aye?  Then she's obviously not got enough to do.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: You work the system right, you could ask her yourself.  Just be thankful you're not working for Household.  The Queen never lets them out of her sight.  But wee spats like us can slip through the net, easy.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: One box of biscuits, one box of drop tablets, one box of pralines, sixteen chocolate sponges.  It's the same order every week, but does anybody bother to check it?  Now she has to travel all the way to Balmoral without the few luxuries she actually enjoys.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: So?  Someone'll send it on ahead.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Aye, but will they?

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: John, it's not your problem what she eats.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: The woman's surrounded by fools!  She has to be packed and ready to leave by seven thirty tomorrow morning.  Knowing that lot, they'll still be dressing her at eight.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: She's got an army of people to get her up and out.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: But I'm the only one she trusts.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: She'll blow hot and cold on you, John, she always does.  You want to be careful.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: I'm on ninety pounds a year plus seventy pounds for a pile of tartan I'd be wearing anyway.  That's as much as a Page of the Back Stairs gets and that job's only for toffs.  I'm Her Majesty's Highland Servant! Indoors and Out.  There's no stopping me now.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: And she sent no word down?

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: They said you were drunk.  Why don't you tell her the truth?

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: She'll think it's her fault for keeping me.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: What are you doing?!

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: I'm getting dressed.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: You've got three broken ribs, man!

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: I've got my duties to attend to.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: Don't be an idiot!  You're in no fit state to go anywhere.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: She'll be worried about me.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: She'll get over it.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: I can't let her down now, Archie.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: And when was the last time she put herself out for you?  Look, John, whatever she says to you now, in the end you're still a servant.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Oh, I'm much more than that.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: Aye, she may say that to you, but the woman can say what she wants.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: You watch your tongue.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: Come on, man, I'm telling you what you already know.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: You know nothing about her!

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: When are you gonna see it, John?  She doesn't give a damn about you.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: My lips may give a message better of Christmas love than e'en this letter.  To my best friend, J.B. from his best friend, V.R.  Best friend!

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: Aye.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: She means it.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: She'll drop you.  When she's done with you, she'll drop you.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Get out.  Out!

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: What's this?

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: It's a diary.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: Be careful who sees it.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: What do you take me for?

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: You should have someone look after you.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: I'm all right.  I just need to rest up a wee bit.  The room ... You don't have to stay.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: The place is a mess.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: I can't move to tidy.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: It's what the maids are for.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: I'm not having some prattler going through my things.

turns.speaker: ARCHIE
turns.text: Won't you give yourself a rest, John? She's other people to look out for her.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: She needs me, Archie.  She canna do without me, she said it to my face.  How can I stop now?

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: What's your name?

turns.speaker: ASSISTANT DRESSER
turns.text: Mary Taylor, sir.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Have I seen you up in Balmoral, Mary?

turns.speaker: ASSISTANT DRESSER
turns.text: I hope to go up next year.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: You wouldn't happen to know what the Queen's reading for recreation, would you, Mary?

turns.speaker: ASSISTANT DRESSER
turns.text: Checked and locked, sir.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Louder, girl!

turns.speaker: ASSISTANT DRESSER
turns.text: Checked and locked, sir.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Kitchen and lower house.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Hey, Barney.

turns.speaker: BARNEY
turns.text: Mr Brown, sir --

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: It's cold out there tonight, Barney.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Yeah, there's a good girl.  Have you had a look at this hoof?  She was limping badly.  I think there might be a stone in it.

turns.speaker: BARNEY
turns.text: Yeah, yeah, I did.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Good man.  And is she all right?

turns.speaker: BARNEY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Good.  She's a good girl.  Aren't you? Yeah, she's a lovely girl.  And you know the Queen's riding tomorrow?

turns.speaker: BARNEY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Are you all right, Barney?

turns.speaker: BERTIE
turns.text: Mr Disraeli.  Ma'am.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: Your Royal Highness.  What a pleasure to see you here.

turns.speaker: BERTIE
turns.text: Have you met Mr Lyle?  He's in sugar...?

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: I don't think I've had that pleasure.

turns.speaker: BERTIE
turns.text: No doubt you've heard the rumors.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: I take no account of gossip, Your Highness.

turns.speaker: BERTIE
turns.text: My concern is for the reputation of the Monarchy.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: BERTIE
turns.text: I fear the influence he has on her. The man's word is not to be credited. He is an arriviste of the very lowest water.  She's having a bust cast of him.  In Nero Marquino marble.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: I see.

turns.speaker: BERTIE
turns.text: I would talk to her myself, but she won't listen to me.  She must be persuaded, by someone she respects, to abandon this ridiculous favoritism before a situation develops.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: A situation?

turns.speaker: BERTIE
turns.text: I don't imagine you frequent the Republican Clubs.  But the fact that neither you nor I are members should not blind us to the significance of their existence.  The Tory Party has always been our party.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: I'm flattered you think so.

turns.speaker: BERTIE
turns.text: I tell you, if we don't stick together on this, you could find yourself First President's Opposition.  Du Royaum Uni.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: Quite.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: It's the Queen's decision.

turns.speaker: BERTIE
turns.text: I beg your pardon?  Mama...?

turns.speaker: BERTIE
turns.text: I wish to see my mother.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: She's busy.

turns.speaker: BERTIE
turns.text: Convey her a message.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: She's away to Windsor tomorrow.  Talk to her there.

turns.speaker: BERTIE
turns.text: Tell her the Prince of Wales wishes to speak with her urgently about matters concerning the press.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Are you deaf as well as stupid?

turns.speaker: BERTIE
turns.text: What did you say?

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: I said, are you deaf as well as stupid?

turns.speaker: BERTIE
turns.text: Do you know who you address, sir?

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Whom you address.

turns.speaker: BERTIE
turns.text: The future King!

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Well, everyone's entitled to their opinion.

turns.speaker: BERTIE
turns.text: Out of my way!

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Gesture?

turns.speaker: BERTIE
turns.text: I thought, a dinner for our ambassadors perhaps?

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: No dinners, Bertie.  Why are you dressed for outdoors?

turns.speaker: BERTIE
turns.text: It's so infernally cold in here.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Cold is good--  Is that not so, Dr. Jenner?!

turns.speaker: BERTIE
turns.text: Mother....

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: ... Least of all my son.  It was his irresponsibility that drove my husband to his grave.

turns.speaker: BERTIE
turns.text: If it is inconvenient to Her Majesty, then perhaps she might consider allowing the Prince of Wales to host--

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: I do believe they send so many boxes to taunt me. Doctor Jenner writes to them to say that my nerves are in an extremely fragile state and yet they continue to hound me with box after box after box after box after box!

turns.speaker: BERTIE
turns.text: Surely it is for the gentlemen to decide when to stop...

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: It is a disgusting habit, Bertie.  It should be discouraged.

turns.speaker: BERTIE
turns.text: Yes, but isn't midnight a little excessive?

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: It is quite late enough.

turns.speaker: BERTIE
turns.text: But mama, the room was built expressly for that purpose.  It has been a smoking-room by tradition ever since father --

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Brown's responsibilities are onerous enough already.  He has far too much to do without having to stay up all night waiting for you to go to bed. The smoking-room will be closed and the lights put out at twelve o'clock.

turns.speaker: BERTIE
turns.text: Mama...

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: And that is my last word on the matter.

turns.speaker: BERTIE
turns.text: Well, I'm sorry, but I really do think it's too much that the gentlemen of the house should be dictated to by a servant.

turns.speaker: BERTIE'S VALET
turns.text: Mr. Carter, the Head Butler, sits there.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Not now he doesn't.  This is my place.

turns.speaker: BERTIE'S VALET
turns.text: By whose authority?

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: My own.

turns.speaker: BERTIE'S VALET
turns.text: The order of seating at the Upper Servant's table is arranged personally by the Queen herself.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: That's a tautology lad.  If you say the Queen arranges something, you've no need to say she's done it personally.  That's understood.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: What happens to John Brown is his business, but the Queen's security will never be compromised!

turns.speaker: BERTIE'S VALET
turns.text: We --

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: You'll talk when I'm finished!

turns.speaker: BERTIE'S VALET
turns.text: Checked and locked, sir.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Back and upper corridors.

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: Her Majesty's routine at Osborne House is not as you will remember it.  The Household remains in full mourning and no-one is permitted to raise their voice under any circumstances whatsoever.  As for the Queen's routine, she breakfasts at nine thirty, lunches at two,takes tea at five thirty and dinner at eight forty five.  No one is allowed to leave the building while the Queen is at home. On the rare occasions when she is out, you may ask permission to leave, but only with my consent. You're to be ready to walk the pony at any time after ten o'clock.  You'll clean her outdoor things and do any odd jobs as and when she requires.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: How will I know?

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: I'm sorry?

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: How will I know what she requires?

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: You'll be sent a message.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Who'll bring it to me?

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: Her Highness' Equerry.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: I need a man who knows where I am.

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: I'm sure it won't be difficult to find you.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: That's not good enough.

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: Then we'll have to see what can be arranged.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Aye, do.

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: There is to be no communication with other members of the household on matters concerning the court except through myself or one of the Equerries.  No plans must be altered unless you are given prior authority by myself or a senior member of the household.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: I came down at the Queen's request. I'll take my orders from her.

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: In matters concerning the Household, I act on her behalf.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Do you?

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: Yes.  I do.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Awaiting my orders.

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: You do not report for duty unless the Queen requests it.  You know that very well.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: I didn't come all this way to sit on my arse.

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: You will await your orders like everyone else.  Unless you prefer a repeat of yesterday's little excitement.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: I beg your pardon?

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: I thought I made myself perfectly clear.  You do not leave your room until Her Majesty requests it.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Well, you tell Her Majesty from me, if her husband was here now, he'd have had her out of that house and getting some air in her.  What the hell's the point in me being here otherwise?!

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: Go inside at once.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Is that the Queen's request?

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: Yes, it most certainly is!

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: She'll be away on Friday between eight o'clock and six in the evening to visit the Grants in Glasalt.  If she's to make the journey there and back in the day she's to have no distractions the night before.  She'll take a light supper alone in her private drawing room and retire early.

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: She'll need to sign dispatches before she retires.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: That can wait till the weekend.

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: There are important papers from --

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: It can wait.  Anything else?

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: If I find out that you had anything to do with this, I will have you sacked.

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: I believe that decision rests with Her Majesty.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Don't think I can't persuade her.

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: I don't doubt that the Queen was highly amused.  She has always had a very healthy sense of humor.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: This is a slur on her good name.

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: In as much as the article is about yourself, I think you must now accept that the public has a right to its interest in you.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Nobody has any rights over me.

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: We are all of us subject to forces beyond our control, Mr Brown, even you.

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: The Queen will be riding to St. George's on the fifth.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: I recommend Her Majesty uses the covered carriage with a full Horse Guard.  In the event of any disturbance I will ensure --

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: What brings you here?

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: A man can refuse only so many invitations from his Queen.  It was remiss of me not to come earlier.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: What do you know about the Highlands?

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: I am a blank sheet.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Do you hunt?

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: Occasionally.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Dare say you can be taught.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: To shoot perhaps, but not to kill.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: If you hunt, you kill.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Always remember, you keep it tight to your shoulder, you absorb the kick. Aim for the head.  Then imagine it's Gladstone.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: Quite.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: You sent for me.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: I've been called back to London.  My last day.  I thought I might take a walk on Lochnagar.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: Princes and Lords are but the breath of kings, An honest man's the noblest work of God.  You must miss such magnificent views.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: I don't think about it.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: Forgive me, I've called you out and you should have been resting.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: I'm fine.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: You're injured.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: It's nothing.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: Still, someone must attend you.  Your wife should not have let you out.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: I'm not married.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: This is the top.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: The look on their faces when one walks into the room.  Still gives one a ridiculous thrill.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: I wouldn't know.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: Surely --

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: What I do, I do for my Queen.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: Was there never ambition?

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Maybe, once.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: Then I envy yo.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: To have achieved one's ambition, or to have reconciled oneself to its limits, is a lifetime's work.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: I do what I do.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: For Her Majesty.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Aye.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: But yourself?  What about John Brown?

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: I said.  I serve the Queen.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: No other aspiration?

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: You will not be unaware of the threat now posed by Republicanism.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Why do you think I keep her here?

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: Ah, but therein lies the paradox.  It is her very isolation that encourages the malcontents.  The longer she is away, the stronger they become; and who, honestly, can promise security against that?  However many doors you lock, someone will always get in. Even here.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: The truth is, the Queen would be safer doing her duty and returning south to her public.  John Bull loves her and John Bull is her best defense.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Her mind is set.  She won't change now.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: She trusts you, John.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: They don't see it.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: See what?

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: The threat.  I tell them, but they don't see it.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: They aren't as watchful as you.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Too busy looking after themselves.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: The greasy pole.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: No loyalty.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: No love.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: I promised to protect her from people like you.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: For once in my life, I am not the issue.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: She'll never understand it.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: In time, she will.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: She'll think I betrayed her.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: But others will know that you acted for the greater good.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Mr Brown.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Ma'am.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: You are here safely.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Aye, ma'am.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: You are well?

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: I am.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: And the pony?

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: She's well, too.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Your family sent cards.  It was much appreciated.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: I'm glad of it.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: My husband was always very complimentary in speaking of you.  He would have approved, I am sure, of my calling on you in this way.  I trust it does not inconvenience you too much.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: I've no family, ma'am, apart from my brothers and sisters.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Yes.  You have a brother in service here, do you not?  I forget his name.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Archie.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Yes.  That will be company for you.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Yes, ma'am.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Mr Brown.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Yes, ma'am.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: You have been told repeatedly not to stand in the courtyard unless requested to do so.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Yes, ma'am.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Then why do you persist in doing it?

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Because I think Her Majesty is wrong. If ever there was a poor soul who needed fresh air, it is her.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: The Queen will ride out if and when she chooses.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: And I intend to be there when she's ready.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Prince Albert was going to build a bench here.  He thought it one of the best views in Osborne.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: It's a fine spot, ma'am.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: He thought so, yes.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: If Prince Albert were here today, he'd tell him a thing or two.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Sir Henry is not alone.  They all wish it.  The same people who refused to grant my husband the title of King because he was deemed of insufficient rank--

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: It is a fine spot for a bench, is it not?

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Aye, ma'am.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: What are those?

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Those, over there, there.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Craobhan-geanmchno-fhiadhaich.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Craobhan-geanmchno...  How can I possibly say that with a straight face?!

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: I am thinking of publishing my "Highland Journals."

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Are they worth reading?

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: I am told so.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Who by?

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Sir Henry Ponsonby tells me they are charming.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: What does he know about the Highlands?

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: He has been attending at Balmoral for many years.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: That doesn't make him an expert.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: His remarks were directed at the quality of the writing, not its subject.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: I don't groom a horse to have it admired by others, I groom it because it needs grooming.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: I do not do it for others.  But Ponsonby thinks they are good.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Just say what you have to say, woman. What other people think shouldn't matter to you.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Of course I shall say what I have to say.  I always do.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Aye, well, if all you want is a good opinion then he'd be sure to oblige you.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: What Mr Ponsonby was appreciating was their literary merit, a skill not intimately associated with the knowledge of grooming.  Literary appreciation does not begin and end with Tennyson.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: They're ready now.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: I hope they didn't go to any trouble, John.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Ah, well...

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: We took a nip of whiskey.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: To keep out the cold.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Aye.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: What is it, John?  John?

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: I heard something.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Must they always follow us?

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: I ordered it.  It's for your own safety.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Dear me, you'll be telling me to watch what I eat next.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Am I not safe enough with you, John?

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Aye.  But there are Fenians reported on the mainland.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: The threat from the Irish is greatly exaggerated, I'm sure.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: I'll decide when it's exaggerated.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: John?

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Yes, ma'am?

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: I was told you were in a fight.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Yes, ma'am.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Has someone seen to those bruises?

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Yes, ma'am.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Ma'am?

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Having considered my position here at court, I have come to the conclusion that it is in the best interest of Your Majesty that I should resign.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: I do not accept.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: I had foreseen that you would not. But Your Majesty should understand -- that my mind will not be changed in this.  I leave for Deeside --

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: The Queen forbids it.  I cannot allow it because I cannot live without you.  Without you, I cannot find the strength to be who I must be.  Please.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Duty?!  You talk about duty?!

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: If duty and safety are served by the same end then, aye, I do.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: I cannot believe you are saying this? You, who I have relied on all this time --

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Have I ever let you down before--?

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: -- You stand there and tell me it is my duty ... after all you promised me!

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: I'm breaking no promises!

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: You are forcing me to do the very thing you know I fear most!

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: For god's sake, woman, I'm just trying to keep you safe!

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: I will not hear any more about my safety!!  You made me a promise and now you have broken it!

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: -- When I took you out riding, come rain or shine, because I knew it was right for you, when I kept the bairns off your back so you could have a bit of peace, when I saw you safe from home to home and you didn't even know I was there...!  All I've ever thought about is you!

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Then why send me back to them?!

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Because I have to!

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: You should never have gone out in such foul weather.

turns.speaker: BROWN
turns.text: Someone has to look after you.  It could've been someone.  It was before.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Yes.  Yes it was.

turns.speaker: DEAN WELLSELLY
turns.text: Forgive me, gentlemen.  I'm late.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: Not at all, Dean.  Good of you to spare the time.

turns.speaker: DEAN WELLSELLY
turns.text: I came as quickly as I could.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: You've seen the latest cartoon in Punch, I take it?

turns.speaker: DEAN WELLSELLY
turns.text: I beg your pardon?

turns.speaker: DEAN WELLSELLY
turns.text: What can we do?

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: Oh, several things.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: Your Majesty remains at the very epicenter of governance.  As for your people, look no further than the sales of your Highland Journals to see in what affection the nation holds their Queen.  You sell even more copies than Mr Dickens.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: But I lack your prose, Mr Disraeli.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Then they may read about me.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: Indeed, and for that they are eternally grateful.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Is that not enough?

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: In so many ways ... and yet it is your presence they crave.  A figurehead.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: I never thought to be bullied by you, Mr Disraeli.  You, I thought, understood a widow's grief.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: Forgive me, ma'am, I cannot speak for the nation, only for myself.  As Prime Minister I confess I miss your presence, but that is only an expression of my own selfish desires and I should not burden you with it.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: I stay here because I am happy.  Is that such a terrible crime?

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: No, ma'am.
